entry.title: Julie Hayden (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that seventeen-year-old Julie Hayden (pictured) was killed by members of the White Man's League days after starting a position teaching Black children, and became "the poster child of southern violence"?

entry.title: Klaus Storck (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Klaus Storck recorded Schubert's Arpeggione Sonata on original instruments, with Alfons Kontarsky at the hammerflügel?

entry.title: science fiction, takes place on Earth (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the vast majority of fiction, including science fiction, takes place on Earth?

entry.title: Bernd Jeffré (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that German paracyclist Bernd Jeffré may have lost his 2010 Berlin Marathon race because he ignored his wife and did not wear enough clothes?

entry.title: medieval Ethiopian kings (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that medieval Ethiopian kings claimed to be descended from Solomon?

entry.title: Dave Siciliano (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that ice hockey coach Dave Siciliano designed his team's dressing room so that players could "look [their] teammates directly in the eye"?

entry.title: a good argument for the existence of numbers (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that some philosophers of mathematics believe that the life cycle of a species of cicadas is a good argument for the existence of numbers?

entry.title: Julie Schmit-Albin (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Julie Schmit-Albin was awarded the title of Admiral in the Great Navy of the State of Nebraska for her work as a pro-life activist?
